G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises from Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in Plaintiff’s residential tenancy pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20132.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court because the Premises are located in Somerville, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant owns and operates residential rental property in Massachusetts and has purposefully availed himself of the privilege of conducting business in this Commonwealth.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is also implied by statute and by law in Plaintiff’s tenancy, regardless of whether it is stated in the lease. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36–37 (1929) (recognizing quiet enjoyment as fundamental to a leasehold).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses an implied obligation arising from the lease—that the landlord will refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises—and recognizes that wrongful interference can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. However, it does not ground this duty in statute (G.L. c. 186, § 14) or state that the covenant is implied ‘by law’ in every tenancy regardless of the lease terms. The court’s reasoning is based on common-law implications from the grant/lease itself, not on a statutory or universally implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant for which injunctive relief might be sought or an action of tort would lie.”

Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.raw_text: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959)
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.proposition: The right to quiet enjoyment is also implied by law in residential tenancies as an incident of the leasehold estate. See Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36–37 (1929) (recognizing covenant of quiet enjoyment as an implied incident of a lease); Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959).
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.support_reasoning: The case deals with a commercial lease for business premises, not a residential tenancy, and it discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction in that commercial context. Nowhere does the opinion state or suggest that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law in residential leases as an incident of the leasehold estate; its analysis is lease-specific and focused on the essential nature of services in an upper-floor business tenancy. Thus, citing this case for the proposition about implied quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies overreads what the decision actually holds.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.relevant_excerpt: "Where tenants lease space on an upper floor of an urban building, as here, to conduct business enterprises, it is unrealistic to say that furnishing light, heat (in our climate), power, and elevator service does not go to the essence of what the landlord is to provide... Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment... and 'enables the lessee to recover the damages... and also provides the lessee with the defense of 'constructive eviction' (if he removes from the premises)."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99\u2013.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 arises not only from his own affirmative acts, but also when he has notice of serious interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment and fails to take reasonable steps within his power to correct it. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–104 (1982) (landlord liable under § 14 for failure to remedy recurring serious conditions); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982) (landlord liable for failing to intervene to stop interference with tenant’s quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” provision and holds that landlords are liable where their conduct, including omissions, recklessly allows serious interferences with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. The court emphasizes that liability does not require malicious intent and that Gem was liable under § 14 because, with knowledge of repeated flooding, it failed to fulfill its duty to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions and thereby permitted recurrent interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that liability arises not only from affirmative acts but also from failure to act after notice of serious interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, we hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.” (385 Mass. at 103–04).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 arises not only from his own affirmative acts, but also when he has notice of serious interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment and fails to take reasonable steps within his power to correct it. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 99–104 (1982) (landlord liable under § 14 for failure to remedy recurring serious conditions); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982) (landlord liable for failing to intervene to stop interference with tenant’s quiet enjoyment).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: Lowery holds that a landlord is liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for failing to provide heat, and emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct rather than intent or financial ability. The case involves the landlord’s own omission in failing to furnish heat—a statutory duty—not a situation where third-party interference with quiet enjoyment occurs and the landlord merely fails to intervene after notice. Thus, it does not address or establish the broader principle that a landlord is liable for failing to stop interference by others once on notice.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: An actionable breach of quiet enjoyment occurs where there is a “substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.” Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994); see also Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977) (substantial noise from adjacent lounge constituted breach of quiet enjoyment).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interference with their tenancy and states that, if tenants are unable to use common areas, this constitutes a serious interference substantially impairing the character of the leased premises. This aligns with the formulation that an actionable breach requires a substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises, and the court applies that standard in remanding for fact-finding on the seriousness of the interference. The citation is therefore accurate and contextually supported.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: An actionable breach of quiet enjoyment occurs where there is a “substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.” Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994); see also Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977) (substantial noise from adjacent lounge constituted breach of quiet enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely finds a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment based on substantial noise and disturbances from an adjacent lounge, and it characterizes the tenants as being “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment “for a substantial time.” The court accepts that this level of interference constitutes a constructive eviction and thus a violation of quiet enjoyment, aligning with the proposition that actionable breach arises from substantial interference with use and enjoyment. The case is therefore an accurate authority for the cited principle, particularly as applied to substantial noise from an adjacent lounge.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’ (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… The landlords do not challenge the judge’s conclusion that the noise emanating from the lounge was sufficient to constitute a constructive eviction, if that noise could be attributed to the landlords.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Similarly, in Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–53 (1997), the Court recognized that a landlord’s knowing failure to remedy conditions substantially interfering with a tenant’s enjoyment, after notice and opportunity to cure, can constitute a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord and that a violation of the lead paint statute alone is insufficient. It then clarifies that to obtain relief under § 14 in a lead-paint context, the tenant must show the landlord had notice or reason to know of the hazardous condition and failed to take appropriate corrective measures—i.e., a knowing failure to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s enjoyment. Thus, the case supports the proposition that a landlord’s knowing failure to cure such conditions after notice can constitute a § 14 violation.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead *851paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Limoli v. Accettullo, 358 Mass. 381, 383.proposition: Moreover, Massachusetts law makes clear that a landlord’s failure to respond to recurring conditions that substantially impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, even where the landlord did not personally create the disturbance. See Simon, 385 Mass. at 99–104; Limoli v. Accettullo, 358 Mass. 381, 383–84 (1970) (landlord liable for failure to act to correct nuisances or interferences within his control).
Limoli v. Accettullo, 358 Mass. 381, 383.support_reasoning: The opinion is a rescission/fraud case about misrepresentation in the sale of real estate and an ice cream business; it does not involve landlord–tenant relations, quiet enjoyment, recurring conditions, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court’s analysis concerns equitable rescission, restitution, and the effect of foreclosure and repossession, not a landlord’s duty to act to correct nuisances or interferences within his control. Accordingly, Limoli does not provide authority for the proposition that a landlord can violate § 14 by failing to respond to recurring conditions impairing a tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Limoli v. Accettullo, 358 Mass. 381, 383.relevant_excerpt: "This is a suit in equity seeking rescission of the plaintiffs’ purchase of real estate, chattels and a retail business from the defendants. The plaintiffs allege that they were induced to make the purchase by intentional misrepresentations by the defendants concerning the existence and condition of sewage disposal facilities on the land. … We are of opinion that because of the circumstances which have brought about the plaintiffs’ inability to restore the real estate and chattels to the defendants, they are not precluded from obtaining equitable relief against the defendants."

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is further reinforced in residential tenancies by G.L. c. 239, § 8A, which allows tenants to assert violations of G.L. c. 186, § 14 as defenses and counterclaims in summary process and reflects the strong public policy in favor of protecting tenants from substantial interferences with their tenancies.

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2.proposition: Additionally, G.L. c. 93A, § 2 and related housing regulations (e.g., 940 C.M.R. 3.17) reflect the Commonwealth’s policy that unreasonable failure to correct serious conditions affecting the use and habitability of residential premises is an unfair or deceptive practice, further underscoring the seriousness with which Massachusetts law treats interference with quiet enjoyment, although Plaintiff does not assert a separate G.L. c. 93A claim in this Complaint.

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who violates the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is liable for actual and consequential damages or, in any event, not less than three months’ rent, and for costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See Al-Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–52; Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains the statutory measure of damages for interference with quiet enjoyment. It states that a lessor who violates § 14 is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee,” and applies that rule to reject the trial judge’s per‑month trebling theory. That matches the proposition’s statement of the statutory remedy, including attorney’s fees.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: An award of costs and statutory interest as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6C and other applicable law;

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff remained current on her rent obligations and fulfilled her duties under the lease, and therefore is entitled to full protection of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973) (recognizing tenant’s right to habitable premises).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring/dissenting opinion in a case where the tenants had admittedly failed to pay rent and were being evicted for nonpayment. The discussion is about implied warranty of habitability and statutory defenses (e.g., G.L. c. 239, § 8A), not about a tenant who has remained current on rent and thereby becomes entitled to full protection of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. This section does not state or imply that timely rent payment and lease compliance are prerequisites to, or confer, special protection of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; instead, it addresses rent withholding and habitability standards.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “These are two actions of summary process under G. L. c. 239 against tenants who admittedly had failed to pay their rent for dwelling units for a number of months. In each action the landlord seeks to recover possession of the dwelling unit and also the unpaid rent. … The situation before us is that tenants who have admittedly withheld payment of rent for apartments which they continued to occupy despite alleged violations of the Code now take the position that by reason of the violations the landlord may neither evict them nor recover any rent from them.”
